articles.title: DECEMBER 1985
articles.summary: This document outlines the December 1985 and January 1986 activities for an astronomy club, featuring general meetings with talks on active mirror telescopes and atmospheric phenomena, alongside several astronomical observation field expeditions. Key announcements include a change to the monthly general meeting date for 1986, new deadlines for newsletter contributions, and ongoing efforts to correct issues with the club's mailing list database.

articles.title: INTRODUCTORY ASTRONOMY
articles.summary: Jack Zeiders will lead an introductory astronomy course starting January 18th at the Gatos Red Cross indoor star parties. This course requires no prior astronomy knowledge or SJAA membership and is designed to run monthly, contingent on sustained interest.

articles.title: MORE ON KONICA 1600
articles.summary: This article discusses the limited availability of Konica 1600 film in Bay Area camera stores, noting Lunicon as the primary source for both unhypered and hypersensitized rolls, with pricing details and a multi-roll discount. It highlights the film's desirable properties like high speed, color balance, and fine grain, acknowledging its high cost. The author also mentions that poor weather has delayed testing of the hypered version.

articles.title: COMET HALLEY ASTROPHOTO'S AVAILABLE
articles.summary: This announcement offers 3Â½ x 5 inch color astrophotographs of Comet Halley, taken on October 13, 1985, with a C14 telescope. These original prints are available for purchase at $50 each, with a full series planned for future release. Interested buyers can acquire them at general meetings, indoor star parties, or request custom 8x10 prints.

articles.title: PHOTOGRAPHING HALLEY'S COMET: DIGGING THROUGH THE ACCESSORY CASE BY: JOHN GLEASON
articles.summary: This article discusses the challenges of astrophotography, specifically capturing Halley's Comet with a Schmidt Cassegrain telescope. The primary issue is the comet's independent motion from the star field, rendering off-axis guiding useless and highlighting problems with separate guide scopes due to differential flexure and the 'sloppy' mirror cells of SCTs. The author suggests alternatives like the piggyback method, or for larger C14 telescopes, utilizing their mirror locking screws to stabilize the primary mirror during long exposures.

articles.title: AS FOR THE OTHER SCHMIDT'S?
articles.summary: This article provides detailed astrophotography tips, particularly for capturing comets like Halley's, covering technical modifications such as using external focusers to eliminate mirror shift on Schmidt-Cassegrain telescopes and ensuring rigid guidescope setups. It offers advice on film selection, exposure times, and appropriate guiding magnifications for both piggyback and prime focus photography. The author also emphasizes the value of wide-field shots, careful lens selection (avoiding zooms), and system balancing for achieving high-quality, sharp images.

articles.title: GREAT RED SPOT
articles.summary: The Great Red Spot (GRS) on Jupiter is currently highly visible, offering a fine show even with smaller instruments, and often appearing pink under good seeing conditions. Despite recent fluctuations in longitude, the Spot's visibility is the best it has been in years. This article marks the closing chapter of the author's column for this Jupiter apparition, with plans to resume observations and articles for the next one, starting July 1987.

articles.title: STAR PARTY, HENRY COE PARK NOVEMBER 9
articles.summary: A star party held at Henry Coe Park on November 9 was prematurely ended by clouds and rain, preventing observers from viewing several anticipated comets. Despite this disappointment, the article announces another star party for December 14 and provides a schedule of Great Red Spot meridian transit times for future observations.

articles.title: BY: DON MACHHOLZ
articles.summary: The article highlights several comets that are, or will be, active in the coming months, noting Comet Thiele and Halley's Comet as prominent in the evening sky, with Halley's expected to reach near naked-eye visibility. It also mentions Comet Giacobini-Zimmer fading and the recovery of the faint periodic comet Boethin (1985n), which was initially found in 1975 and has an 11-year orbital period.

articles.title: EPHEMERIDES
articles.summary: This article provides ephemerides for Comet Hartley-Good and Comet Thiele (1985M) for the period from late November to early January, including their right ascension, declination, elongation, and magnitude. It details observational characteristics such as their closest approaches to the sun and Earth, visibility conditions, and apparent size, noting that Comet Hartley-Good is a fine comet but diffuse, while Comet Thiele is fainter and also diffuse.

articles.title: WHAT GOES AROUND COMES AROUND - HALLEY'S
articles.summary: This article serves as an observing guide for Halley's Comet in December, detailing its celestial path through Pisces and Aquarius, optimal viewing periods based on moon phases, and specific coordinates for December 14th. It provides comprehensive tips for amateur astronomers on how to observe and analyze the comet's physical characteristics, such as its motion, brightness, shape, color, tail features, and coma details using various instruments. An ephemeris table with positions and magnitudes for Halley's Comet through early January is also included, along with a historical note on comets named after orbit calculators.

articles.title: A LATE UPDATE BY: JOHN GLEASON
articles.summary: This article recounts an astronomer's challenging attempts to observe and photograph Halley's Comet in November, initially frustrated by persistent overcast weather at prime observing sites. Despite these setbacks and a previously spoiled film, the author made a successful, albeit desperate, attempt to photograph the comet from a light-polluted city location. This experiment, using hypersensitized Konica 1600 film and a deep sky filter, surprisingly yielded excellent results, demonstrating the feasibility of deep sky photography from urban areas and proving the film's sustained sensitivity.

articles.title: ASTRO ADS
articles.summary: Ira Weiss is advertising a C8 telescope for sale. Additionally, he is seeking an individual with basic astronomy knowledge to recruit 20 or more people for a free comet tour, with most other tour responsibilities handled by Weiss, a travel agent.

articles.title: BY: JAY REYNOLDS FREEMAN
articles.summary: This article details the author's recent astronomical activities, including leading a naked-eye astronomy lecture at a star party, offering advice on how to conduct effective star talks, and sharing personal observing reports. Key observations include faint galaxies in Abell 347, the edge-on spiral NGC 891, and Comet Halley, where the author discusses the challenge of observing its faint coma with different magnifications. The author also recounts successful observations of various nebulae (Merope, NGC 2024, NGC 2023, Orion complex) from both dark sites and an in-town location.

articles.title: CHALLENGER COMPLETES GERMAN SPACELAB FLIGHT
articles.summary: The Space Shuttle Challenger successfully completed its German Spacelab mission (61-A), launching on October 30th and landing on November 6th at Edwards AFB. This historic flight was the first where payload control was shifted to the U.S., achieving over 80% success with its 75 experiments, many of which were saved by in-flight repairs. Nose wheel steering tests conducted during landing were crucial, enabling future shuttle landings at Kennedy Space Center.

articles.title: ATLANTIS SETS ALTITUDE RECORD
articles.summary: During mission 51-J in October, the Space Shuttle Atlantis set a new altitude record of 320 miles. This record is anticipated to be broken by the planned launch of the Hubble Space Telescope on August 8, 1986, also aboard Atlantis, which is scheduled to reach an altitude of 368 miles.

articles.title: ATLANTIS SCHEDULED FOR 27 NOV. LAUNCH
articles.summary: Space Shuttle Atlantis is scheduled to launch on November 27 for its 61-B mission. The five-day flight will carry a payload of three communication satellites and an electrophoresis drug purification system, with a crew of seven.

articles.title: COLUMBIA SCHEDULED FOR 20 DEC LAUNCH
articles.summary: The Space Shuttle Columbia (mission 61-C) is slated for launch on December 20, marking the final shuttle flight of the year. This 7-day mission, with a crew of 7, will deploy two communication satellites and conduct two experiments: the Materials Science Laboratory (MSL-2) and the Experimental Assembly of Structures in EVA (ease/access).
keywords: Experimental Assembly of Structures in EVA

articles.title: LEASAT 3 ACHIEVES GEOSYNCHRONOUS ORBIT
articles.summary: The LEASAT 3 satellite successfully achieved geosynchronous orbit on October 27th after being repaired by the Space Shuttle Discovery crew during Mission 51-I, with operational status expected by November 30th. Separately, the article details observations of the galaxies Messier 81 and 82, noting their distinct appearances through a four-inch refractor and mentioning enhanced views with larger telescopes.

articles.title: REPORTER TO BE SELECTED FOR A SHUTTLE FLIGHT
articles.summary: NASA announced its decision to select a news reporter to participate in the Space Flight Participant Program. The selected reporter will fly aboard a Space Shuttle in the fall of 1986.

articles.title: SOVIET VERSION OF NASA
articles.summary: The USSR has established Glavkosmos, a new civilian space agency, to manage Soviet space programs and application projects. This agency will also oversee the nation's participation in international space ventures, focusing on the creation and use of space technology for economic and scientific research.

articles.title: SOVIETS BUILDING NEW SPACE STATION
articles.summary: The Soviet Union is constructing a new modular Salyut space station, scheduled for launch in 1986. This upcoming station is designed with expandability in mind, promising to be larger than previous Salyut models.

articles.title: SOVIET PHOBOS MISSION PLANNED
articles.summary: The Soviet Union is planning a dual spacecraft mission to Phobos, one of Mars' moons, in 1988. The mission involves the spacecraft entering a 30 km orbit around Phobos, with periodic descents to just 50 meters above its surface for study.

articles.title: U.S. MARS MISSION PLANNED
articles.summary: The U.S. is planning a Mars mission, the Mars Observer, with a launch scheduled for 1990. The scientific objectives of this mission are heavily influenced by growing evidence suggesting the presence of a significant amount of water on Mars.

articles.title: SHUTTLE HALLEY COMET MISSION SCHEDULED
articles.summary: NASA's Space Shuttle Columbia is scheduled for launch on March 6th for Mission 61-E. Its primary objective is to study Halley's Comet from Earth orbit using a payload of three ultraviolet telescopes and a visible light, wide-field camera. The mission is planned for an 8-day duration with a seven-person crew.

articles.title: GALILEO UNDERGOING FINAL TESTS
articles.summary: The Galileo spacecraft is currently undergoing its final tests in preparation for its upcoming launch. It is scheduled for shipment to Kennedy Space Center in December, with the launch itself anticipated for late May.

articles.title: AGREEMENT TO DEVELOP SATELLITE TRANSFER VEHICLE SIGNED
articles.summary:
## AGREEMENT TO DEVELOP SATELLITE TRANSFER VEHICLE SIGNED

NASA and Scott Science and Technology have agreed on development of a commercial, liquid-fueled upper stage for boosting shuttle-deployed sat...

articles.title: ASTRO ADS
articles.summary: An advertisement by Bob Jensen offers a professionally made 6" F/17 refractor telescope for sale at $1600. The refractor features a machined aluminum tube with internal baffles, a rack & pinion focusing tailpiece, and includes spotting scope brackets, a balancing assembly, and a saddle for a German mounting. Interested members are encouraged to call for details.

articles.title: Panel 1
articles.summary: Two characters, each seemingly associated with a building topped with a telescope, engage in a brief, humorous exchange. One character comically wonders why no one tries to corrupt morals anymore, while the other excitedly announces the arrival of the new San Jose Astronomical Association Bulletin in the mail.

articles.title: Panel 2
articles.summary: Panel 2 depicts a brief, contentious dialogue between "First building" and "Second building" over who gets to read something. The "Second building" vehemently insists it's their turn, claiming the "First building" had the last opportunity, leading to an escalating demand for immediate access.

articles.title: Panel 3
articles.summary: The short text, labeled 'Panel 3' and seemingly part of a larger publication identified as 'TELESCOPE', features a humorous meta-commentary on its own content. It expresses mock surprise and disappointment that the current issue contains no obscene quotes whatsoever. This self-referential comment highlights an unexpected absence for the publication.

articles.title: Panel 4
articles.summary: This brief excerpt, titled "Panel 4," describes an ongoing activity centered around "Building with TELESCOPE." The text conveys a sense of intrigue and suspicion, prompting a question about the unknown intentions behind this construction.

articles.title: GENERAL MEETINGS:
articles.summary: This document outlines the details for general meetings, which are held monthly at the Los Gatos Red Cross building in Los Gatos, California. This location also hosts the SJAA's "Indoor Star Parties." Specific directions to the venue at 16011 Los Gatos-Saratoga Rd are provided, noting that meetings consistently begin at 8 PM.

articles.title: GRANT RANCH COUNTY PARK:
articles.summary: Grant Ranch County Park is identified as a popular observing site for the San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA) on Mt. Hamilton Road. The article provides detailed directions to the park and instructions for after-sunset access using a combination lock (4565) on the front gate. It also mentions an additional observing area within the county park further up Mt. Hamilton Road.

articles.title: HENRY COE STATE PARK:
articles.summary: This document provides detailed driving directions to Henry Coe State Park, starting from Hwy 101 South towards Gilroy and using the East Dunne exit. It also specifies access instructions for a locked gate with a club combination (4565) and outlines rules for night arrivals, including parking outside the gate initially and using only parking lights once inside.

articles.title: FREMONT PEAK STATE PARK:
articles.summary: This document provides detailed driving directions to Fremont Peak State Park, specifically guiding visitors to Coulter Camp, which is a setup location for the San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA). It emphasizes using parking lights only after dark to maintain an optimal observing environment. The document is published by the San Jose Astronomical Association.

articles.title: OFFICERS:
articles.summary: This document lists the current officers of an organization, including the President, Vice-President, Secretary, and Treasurer. For each position, it provides the officer's name, mailing address, and telephone number, serving as a contact directory for the organization's leadership.

articles.title: BOARD OF DIRECTORS:
articles.summary: This document provides a directory of the Board of Directors, listing the names and corresponding phone numbers for each member. It serves as a contact list for the organization's leadership.

articles.title: EPHEMERIS EDITOR:
articles.summary: The provided article snippet is extremely brief, consisting only of a title "EPHEMERIS EDITOR" and contact information for John P. Gleason. No actual content or details about the editor are present, making a comprehensive summary impossible.

articles.title: SAN JOSE ASTRONOMICAL ASSOCIATION MEMBERSHIP APPLICATION
articles.summary: This document is a membership application form for the San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA). It details different membership options, including standard, membership with Sky & Telescope magazine, and junior membership, along with their respective fees. The form provides fields for personal information and instructions for submission via mail or in person at an SJAA meeting.

articles.title: Questionnaire (optional)
articles.summary:
## Questionnaire (optional)

What are your astronomical interests (e.g. astrophotography, deep-sky observation, telescope making, etc.)? _______________________________________________

______________...

articles.title: COMET MACHHOLZ (1985e)
articles.summary: The article reports the discovery of Comet Machholz (1985e) on May 27, 1985, by the author at the Riverside Telescope Makers Conference. This marks the author's second comet find, made using a 10-inch f/3.8 reflector after 1742 hours of sweeping. The comet is currently brightening in the morning sky, expected to be lost in solar glare in mid-June, potentially visible in daylight, and will re-emerge in the evening sky in mid-July before dimming by mid-August; preliminary orbital elements are also provided.

articles.title: EPHEMERIS
articles.summary: This document provides an astronomical ephemeris, a table detailing the celestial coordinates (Right Ascension and Declination), visual magnitude, elongation, and distances from the Sun and Earth for a celestial object across various dates from May 30th to August 18th. The data includes visibility in the morning or evening sky and shows how the object's brightness changes over time, reaching a peak magnitude of -0.6 on June 29th.

articles.title: A SHORT SEARCH EPHEMERIS:
articles.summary: The document provides a short search ephemeris for an celestial object, detailing its Right Ascension, Declination, and Magnitude for dates from June 1st to June 9th at 4 AM PDT. It serves as a guide for observers and includes contact information for updated data from Sky and Telescope and Don Machholz.
